review.title: SAS+ Planning as Satisfiability
review.abstract: Planning as satisfiability is a principal approach to planning with many eminent advantages. The existing planning as satisfiability techniques usually use encodings compiled from STRIPS. We introduce a novel SAT encoding scheme (SASE) based on the SAS+ formalism. The new scheme exploits the structural information in SAS+, resulting in an encoding that is both more compact and efficient for planning. We prove the correctness of the new encoding by establishing an isomorphism between the solution plans of SASE and that of STRIPS based encodings. We further analyze the transition variables newly introduced in SASE to explain why it accommodates modern SAT solving algorithms and improves performance. We give empirical statistical results to support our analysis. We also develop a number of techniques to further reduce the encoding size of SASE, and conduct experimental studies to show the strength of each individual technique. Finally, we report extensive experimental results to demonstrate significant improvements of SASE over the state-of-the-art STRIPS based encoding schemes in terms of both time and memory efficiency.

sections.heading: 5. SAT Solving Efficiency on Different Encodings
sections.text: In Section 4, we have shown that PE and SASE are semantically equivalent because they share the same solution space. In this section, we will examine what distinguishes them in terms of the efficiency of the SAT solution. In particular, we want to understand how PE and SASE induce a SAT solver to behave differently in the same planning task. Modern SAT solvers, which all use many sophisticated techniques nowadays, are too complicated to be characterized by simple models. In general, it is difficult to accurately estimate the time it takes for a SAT solver to solve a SAT instance. In this section, we will provide an explanation of why SAT codes from SASE are more efficient for SAT solvers than SAT codes from PE and provide empirical evidence to support this explanation.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and Future Research
sections.text: In this paper, we developed a novel SAS + -based SAT encoding scheme SASE and demonstrated that it improves the efficiency of STRIPS-based SAT encodings in terms of both time and memory. SASE has clear advantages over modern SAT-based planners, as our experimental analysis showed. We proved the accuracy of SASE encoding by showing that there is an isomorphism between SASE's solution plans and SatPlan06's solution plans. We went on to analyze SASE's search space structure and explain why it is more efficient.

sections.heading: 8.2 Additional Techniques for Planning as SAT
sections.text: The enormous amount of bilingual clauses (such as the mutual exclusion clauses in the case of planning) presents a key challenge for approaches based on satisfaction tests. It has been proposed to reduce the burden of coding by recognizing certain structures (Brafman, 2001). In traditional SAT planning systems such as SatPlan06, the mutual exclusions are encoded square. Rintanen proposes a protocol size representation (Rintanen, 2006), called clique representation, for the mutual exclusion limitations, and later a linear size one (Rintanen et al., 2006). Mutual exclusions in SASE are represented by the clique representation. The protocol size of client representation is said to be less compact than the linear coding. However, our results have shown that SASE is generally more compact (SASE et al., 2006). This is mainly due to the compactness of SAS + formalism.

sections.heading: 8.3 More Understanding of Structure in General SAT Instances
sections.text: It is therefore interesting and important to understand why SAT solutions work well in certain cases, and beyond what makes an SAT instance easy or difficult. There is much previous research that attempts to gain such an understanding, including Backdoor Set (Williams, Gomes, & Selman, 2003) and Backbone (Monasson, Zecchina, Kirkpatrick, Selman, & Troyansky, 1999; Zhang, Rangan, & Looks, 2003; Zhang, 2004). Backdoor Set Variables are a set of variables, so when these variables are assigned, the assignments of other variables can be derived in polynomial time. Backbone variables are those that have the same mapping in all valid solutions, which can be further exploited to improve SAT solution efficiency.
